speaker: Frasier
text: Are your eyes closed?

speaker: Niles
text: What is it?  _Frasier places a huge, gorgeously elaborate antique chess set on the table._

speaker: Frasier
text: It's something my antiques scout found for me.  Voila! [_Niles opens his eyes and gapes_] Paris, 1882!  Designed by Jean- Francois Blon, while attending _L'Ecole des Beaux Arts!_

speaker: Niles
text: _Mon Dieu!_  It's absolutely breathtaking!  I'm breathless! [_gasps_] I need to take a breath.

speaker: Daphne
text: Evening, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Would you like to try a game, Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I think not.  It'll make me too melancholy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, all right.

speaker: Niles
text: Maris and I used to play chess every Thursday night.  Oh, how she loved the game.

speaker: Frasier
text: No wonder -- the king is stationary while the queen has all the power.

speaker: Daphne
text: How are you getting along, Dr. Crane?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, all right, I guess.

speaker: Daphne
text: Feeling a bit lonely, are we?

speaker: Niles
text: Only some times when I'm by myself, or other times when I'm with other people.

speaker: Daphne
text: It may not be my place to suggest this, but perhaps all you need is a little company at the apartment -- something warm and friendly to come home?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I'm sure Dad would miss you.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_laughs and bats his arm_] Oh, Dr. Crane!

speaker: Niles
text: [_laughs and bats himself_] Oh, me!

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm talking about a dog.  They're wonderful companions.  Just look at how much Eddie's brought to your father's life.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, there's nothing like a dog's unconditional love.  Seeing that smiling face greet you at the door.  It's one of the most rewarding relationships a person can have.

speaker: Daphne
text: Again?  If you're going to drink out of the toilet, you can at least learn to use it. [_she fits the leash on Eddie_] Would you like to come with me?  Maybe get the feel of the leash?

speaker: Niles
text: [_when she puts it that way_] Perhaps I will.

speaker: Niles
text: You know, Daphne, maybe you're on to something with this dog business.  I'm starting to feel less lonely already.  _He shuts the door on the leash, trapping Eddie inside.  He opens the door again._

speaker: Niles
text: Chop, chop!  Come with us.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hi, Dad.  Did you see my new chess set?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh yeah, it's nice.

speaker: Frasier
text: "Nice?"  Well, the inlay was made from the same Travertine marble they used at the Emperor Hadrian's palace outside Tivoli!

speaker: Martin
text: Really?  Well, I'm gonna celebrate with a beverage brewed from the crystal-clear waters of the majestic Colorado Rockies!

speaker: Frasier
text: Good one, Dad.  Say, how about a game?

speaker: Martin
text: Nah, I don't think so.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, come on, Dad.  You know how to play, don't you?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, Daphne showed me once.  But really, checkers is more my speed.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, come on, checkers is a kid's game.  Come on, Dad!  I just got it!  Please?  Nobody will play with me!

speaker: Martin
text: All right, I'll give it another shot. [_sits opposite Frasier and pulls his chair up to the table_] Those guys at the park make it look great--eating baloney sandwiches, smoking cigars, sometimes a fist-fight even breaks out!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, let's just start with name-calling and see where it goes, all right?  _Frasier moves.  DISSOLVE TO: a While Later. The game is almost finished.  Frasier moves._

speaker: Frasier
text: Your turn.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, Dad, please, you don't have to rush.  As a novice, you have the right to sit back, survey the board, take your time.  I will not pressure you or hover like a vulture. Please, feel free to ask any questions you might have.

speaker: Martin
text: Is this a checkmate?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_looking_] Yes, it is.

speaker: Martin
text: You mean I won?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, yes.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, hey!  I won!  How do you like that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, in all fairness, my mind was a bit distracted by having to monitor your side of the board, but, uh... Touche!  How about another game, Dad?

speaker: Martin
text: No, I think one'll do it for me, thanks.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, uh, all right, fair enough.

speaker: Martin
text: Boy, I really clobbered you though, didn't I?  I got almost all of your prawns.

speaker: Frasier
text: Pawns, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: I think the turning point was when I got that tower-thingy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, it's called a rook.

speaker: Martin
text: But the real knockout blow was when I backed your little horsey-guy into the corner.

speaker: Frasier
text: Can we call it a night, Dad?

speaker: Martin
text: O.K., when I cornered your knight.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I mean can we call it a night?  _Martin shrugs and goes to his room.  Frasier continues to stew.  FADE OUT_  **MAYBE IT'S SHORT FOR NODULE**  _Scene Two -- Cafe Nervosa Frasier is sitting at a corner table, replaying the previous night's chess game with a small pocket set.  Roz sits at his table._

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh hi, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Uh, one double-tall latte, a slice of pecan pie with extra whipped cream.

speaker: Waitress
text: Anything else?

speaker: Frasier
text: Perhaps a blood-pressure cuff?

speaker: Roz
text: I'm just a little nervous today, O.K.?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, really?  Trouble on the dating front?

speaker: Roz
text: I'm not that shallow, all right?  It's about my hair. I've got an appointment this afternoon with Noge.

speaker: Frasier
text: "Noge?"

speaker: Roz
text: He's the hottest hairstylist in Seattle?

speaker: Frasier
text: "Noge?"

speaker: Roz
text: I think he's getting a little bored with me.  When he cuts my hair, I can't ever think of anything to say!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, how's this for an icebreaker: "Say, Noge, where'd you get such a stupid name?"

speaker: Roz
text: You should see him with all of his other clients.  They're all laughing, having a wonderful time.  I walk in, sit down, it's death. [_picks up newspaper_] Maybe there's something in here that'll hold his attention. [_reads_] Oh, wow, here's something.  A lady in Italy gave birth to a nineteen-pound baby!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh my God.

speaker: Roz
text: No kidding.  She's not going to be hopping on her Vespa anytime soon.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's how he did it.

speaker: Roz
text: What are you talking about?

speaker: Frasier
text: My father beat me at chess last night, and I've just realized now it was sheer dumb luck.  He stumbled into the Panov-Botvinnik attack!

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, I--

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Roz, I can't tell you what a relief this is.  My God, my whole world makes sense again.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, you are forgetting about my problem with Noge.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and it'd be a lot easier if you'd stop bringing it up. **AND SHE'S HYPOGLYCEMIC**  _Scene Three -- Frasier's Apartment It's evening.  The doorbell rings, and Frasier opens the door to Niles. _

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: To what do I owe this pleasure?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I took to heart Daphne's suggestion the other day about a need for companionship since my separation from Maris, so I went out and got a new lady in my life. _Niles leads in Girl -- a pencil-thin Whippet with a narrow, curving spine, tall skinny legs, and blue-white fur._

speaker: Niles
text: I can't explain it.  I'm not a dog person, but there's something about this particular breed that I find comforting and familiar.  It's mystifying, isn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Mmm, baffling.

speaker: Niles
text: I-I happened into my local pet shop, and I had no intention of buying anything, I was merely browsing, and they showed me some overly demonstrative puppies.  Then I heard a haughty little sniff from a cage in the corner, and there she was! [_to Girl_] Sit, Girl, sit! [_Girl doesn't move_] OK. [_to Frasier_] She's, uh, she's a bit high strung, but, uh, she's terribly well-bred.  When I tried to pet her, she'd have none of it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm surprised she wasn't snapped up before you got there.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, well, the man at the pet store said it's because people are reluctant to take responsibility for her nerve medicine.

speaker: Niles
text: No, not on the couch.  Off, off! [_Girl doesn't move_] OK.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: [_notices Girl_] What the hell is that?

speaker: Niles
text: It's my dog, my new best friend.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Niles saw her in the pet store and had this inexplicable attraction.

speaker: Martin
text: You can see her ribs!

speaker: Frasier
text: Hit Number One.

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne, I owe it all to you.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_laughing nervously_] Oh really, Dr. Crane, I wouldn't want you going around telling people I was responsible for that.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I guess we'll be toddling along. [_gets up_] Come Girl, come! [_Girl doesn't move_] OK. [_picks her up and carries her to the door_] The city streets play havoc with her delicate little feet, so I have to go home and pumice her paw-pads!

speaker: Daphne
text: Am I the only one?

speaker: Frasier/Martin
text: No.

speaker: Daphne
text: Does Dr. Crane have any idea...

speaker: Frasier/Martin
text: No.

speaker: Frasier
text: So, Dad, can I, uh, interest you in an ice-cold Ballantine?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, sounds good.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I may even join you myself.  I've got some pork rinds here and some of that creamy Lipton onion soup dip!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, with the seven herbs and spices?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, just count 'em! _Frasier sets down two cold beers and a snack tray filled with pork rinds, potato chips, and dip on the table, then goes back into the kitchen.  Martin sits in a chair._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, that's great!  All my favorite stuff... you're putting me in a home, aren't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_laughing_] Oh, don't be silly!  But you know, if I ever had to, don't you think it'd be nice if you knew how to play chess? _Frasier emerges from the kitchen with his chess set.  Martin realizes he's been duped.  DISSOLVE TO: a While Later. It's Frasier's turn.  Very slowly, he picks up his piece and sets it down, then even more slowly starts to remove his hand, leaving his fingertip for last.  Martin reaches for a piece._

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, it's not considered a move until my fingers have completely cleared the piece.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, what's taking so long?

speaker: Frasier
text: I am analyzing my options.  Unlike your "wing-it" approach, I like to plan a strategy, like a general leading his troops into battle.

speaker: Martin
text: Checkmate, Schwartzkopf.

speaker: Frasier
text: Gosh, that's very well done.  You're really getting a feel for the game, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, and all this time I thought chess was hard. [_gets up_] Well, see ya.

speaker: Frasier
text: Sit down, old man, you're not going anywhere!  _Martin sighs and sits down again.  DISSOLVE TO: A While Later While Frasier stares intently at the board, Martin is sitting in an armchair, goofing around with Eddie._

speaker: Daphne
text: [_o.s._] Mr. Crane, would you give me a hand with these dishes?

speaker: Martin
text: I can't, I'm playing chess with Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Finally, my patience will be rewarded.  The trap is set. I knew this moment would come!

speaker: Martin
text: It comes every game.  _Martin comes back to the table, takes a quick look without sitting down, and moves._

speaker: Martin
text: Checkmate.  Well, that's it.  Show's over, folks.  Move along. Nothing more to see here.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Dad--

speaker: Martin
text: No, no, I'm not playing anymore.  I'm tired and I'm going to bed.

speaker: Frasier
text: O.K. [_chuckling_] Yes, I guess I've had my fill as well. Well, this has really turned out to be quite a good idea, hasn't it, this chess thing?

speaker: Martin
text: 'Night.

speaker: Frasier
text: Awfully relaxing... oh, yes, yes, you just -- you just go on ahead, I-I've got -- hah! -- something I've got to do... _Frasier, still chuckling, picks up a cushion from the couch and goes out onto the balcony.  Closing the door behind him, he mashes the cushion into his face and howls into it.  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO  Scene Four -- Cafe Nervosa Roz is standing at the bar with a cup of coffee.  Frasier comes in._

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Frasier!

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: I have great news!  My appointment with Noge could not have gone better.

speaker: Frasier
text: What is the reason behind this miraculous transformation?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, it occurred to me that hairstylists love celebrity gossip.  And I thought, "hey, I know a celebrity: you!"

speaker: Frasier
text: [_wary_] And what did you tell him about me?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, he may have gotten the impression that you-- [_laughs fraudulently_] -- well, you're gonna love this -- that, you know... you may have been... in the past... a woman, you're not mad at me, are you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Mad?  Why should I be mad, knowing the sacred code of silence all hairdressers have sworn to?

speaker: Roz
text: All right, I'll set Noge straight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, if you manage that, then you really would have a story.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, hello. [_to waitress_] Double cappuccino, please.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, same for me, please. [_to Niles_] Listen, Niles, I need to talk to you about Dad.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh yes, how is the Bobby Fischer of the geriatric circuit?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, he's still beating me.  I tell you, Niles, I just can't figure it out -- I am the superior player.

speaker: Niles
text: There's a saying: "In every boy's life, the moment of greatest joy and greatest sorrow is when he defeats his father for the first time."

speaker: Frasier
text: If you're suggesting that I'm afraid to beat Dad, you can just stop right there.

speaker: Niles
text: O.K.  The other option is, he's better than you.

speaker: Frasier
text: You were saying?

speaker: Niles
text: Sooner or later, the son eclipses the father.  It's the natural order.  Yet it's frequently a stumbling block because the son's competitive stirrings are accompanied by tremendous feelings of guilt.

speaker: Frasier
text: I see.  Yes, it's the classic Oedipal conflict.  It seems so obvious now.  I've been letting him win!  Niles, thank you, thank you very much.  I can't tell you what a relief this is. I feel like a weight has been lifted.  Nothing can hold me back now.  Tonight, I topple the king!

speaker: Niles
text: Hear, hear.

speaker: Niles
text: Of course, you realize by dethroning Dad, you're next in line to be dethroned by Frederick, and then the only thing left after that is death, but that's another day and another cup of coffee.  _Frasier gives him a look.  FADE TO:  Scene Five -- Frasier's Apartment It's late evening.  Frasier and Martin are back at the table. Frasier is tense and alert, while Martin is tired and can barely keep his eyes open.  Frasier moves._

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad?  Dad, wake up, it's your turn.

speaker: Martin
text: [_waking up; sleepy_] Oh, I'm sorry... [_moves_] Checkmate. Well, I'm going to bed.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, come on, Dad, just one more game!

speaker: Martin
text: No!  I can't keep my eyes open. _Martin goes to his room.  Frasier goes over to the couch, and selects a cushion.  He pats it softly, as if fluffing it.  Then, he slaps it with the back of his hand.  Before long, he's whaling on it with his fist, beating the stuffing out of it like a punching bag.  Daphne comes in with a basket of laundry and sees him.  Noticing her, he stops._

speaker: Daphne
text: Playing chess again, were you?  _Frasier sinks onto the couch.  Daphne takes a sock from the basket and slips it over her arm._

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, Dr. Crane, when one of my brothers would lose a soccer match, he'd be all blue and in the dumps.  But I could get him to laugh.  I'd make a little puppet like so. [_moving the puppet's lips; deep, round voice_] Hello, Daphne, What's shaking? [_her voice_] Oh, hello, Freddy.  My friend Dr. Crane here forgot his happy pants! [_Freddy_] Oh, no!  What should I do? [_Daphne_] Would you sing for him? [_Freddy_] I'd love to. [_sticking the puppet close to Frasier's face; singing_] Who's that grouchy gus I see?  You can't be grouchy, not with me! Sing along, Doc!  Who's that grouchy gus I see--

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, I would rather have a tarantula lay eggs in my ear than listen to any more of this puppet show.  Do we understand each other?  _He nods the puppet "yes," up and down.  FADE TO:_  **CHESS PAINS**  _Scene Six -- Frasier's Apartment It's late at night.  Frasier walks up to Martin's door in his dressing gown.  He opens the door and peeks in.  Martin is fast asleep, with Eddie sleeping beside him.  Frasier reaches in and flicks the lights on and off, then closes the door again.  After waiting a few moments, he peeks in.  Martin is still asleep._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_whispering_] Eddie!  Speak!  Speak, Eddie!  _Eddie is still asleep.  Frasier closes the door, gets a book of matches out of the hallway bureau, and tears one out.  Chuckling deviously, he strikes the match and sets the rest of them on fire.  Then he quickly blows them out, producing a puff of smoke, which he holds up to the smoke detector. Immediately, the fire alarm goes off, beeping loudly.  Frasier dashes back into his room.  Martin rushes out of his room, carrying Eddie in one arm and pounding on doors with his cane._

speaker: Martin
text: Fire!  Fire, everybody!  Frasier!  Daphne!  Fire!  Fire!

speaker: Frasier
text: What's going on?!

speaker: Martin
text: The fire alarm went off, but I don't see anything around here!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_rushing in_] It's not in my room, either!

speaker: Frasier
text: It's O.K.! [_laughing_] My fault, false alarm.  I was just a little remiss in replacing the batteries, everything's fine. [_turns off alarm_]

speaker: Daphne
text: The batteries?  No, smoke alarms don't go off if--

speaker: Frasier
text: Back to bed!

speaker: Martin
text: See you in the morning.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you know, seeing as how we're both up, I thought maybe we should, oh I dunno, do something, you know?

speaker: Martin
text: Like what?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, uh, right off the top of my head, I... well, play a little chess?

speaker: Martin
text: Now?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, sure!  We're both wide awake.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh my God, you set that alarm off!

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad!  I--I had no--

speaker: Martin
text: What kind of weird, competitive freak are you?  I mean, you really hate to lose so much that you wake up the whole house and scare us all to death?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, of course not!  And I wouldn't have to resort to such lengths if this damn dog could learn to speak! [_Eddie barks_] Oh, of course, now you'll get it right!  Look, Dad, would one more game kill you?  I mean, you're all riled up.  My God, you'll never get to sleep now anyway!

speaker: Martin
text: Wait a minute.  This isn't about losing, is it?  This is about losing to _me._  That's what's driving you nuts! "How could I lose to the old man?  I'm much smarter than he is!"

speaker: Frasier
text: I never said that!

speaker: Martin
text: No, you didn't have to say it, you've thought it all your life!

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I haven't!

speaker: Martin
text: Yes, you have, and now you're insulting my intelligence again!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Dad!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, now listen, what do you think I was doing as a detective all those years?  Analyzing clues, devising strategies, trying to stay one or two steps ahead of the other guys -- now, does that sound like any game that you know?

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, that explains why you can play the game, but not why you beat me every time!  Now, come on, just one more game, please?  Dad, look, I'll never bring it up again!  Come on!

speaker: Martin
text: No.  Why should I?  You just want to beat me so that you can go back to thinking you're smarter than your stupid old man. Well, forget it, to hell with you.  I don't see any reason why I should ever play you again.

speaker: Frasier
text: If you win, I'll give you five thousand dollars.

speaker: Martin
text: Get out of my way.  _Martin gets out of bed, grabs his cane, and limps past Frasier. They come out into the living room._

speaker: Martin
text: Well, look at that, the board's all set up!  What a surprise.

speaker: Frasier
text: I took the liberty.  Now, Dad, I think we can sit down and play a nice cordial little game.  For centuries, people have set aside their differences to play a game of chess.  So, who should go first?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, let's see.  It's usually the person who lost the last game.  Now, who could that be?

speaker: Frasier
text: OK.  No more Mr. Cordial Guy!  _He moves a pawn.  DISSOLVE TO Later: the game has advanced. Frasier lifts one of his pieces._

speaker: Martin
text: By the way, I'm sorry the ratings for your show took a dive last month.

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't try to pull your cheap psychological tricks on me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, did I mention... the cemetery called?  Apparently they have to dig a sewer next to your plot.  _Martin puts his piece down.  DISSOLVE TO Even Later: The game is now in it's final stages.  Eddie is perched on a chair, staring at Frasier._

speaker: Frasier
text: Getting your dog to stare at me only proves how desperate you are. [_moves_]

speaker: Martin
text: I didn't tell him to do that.  He just gets fascinated when he sees people sweat. [_moves_]

speaker: Frasier
text: I sweat when I'm happy. [_moves_]

speaker: Martin
text: Well, then you must be ecstatic! [_moves, then_] No, wait!

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, you took your finger off that piece!

speaker: Martin
text: No, I didn't!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, you did!  That means that you must not trust that move, must have left yourself vulnerable somewhere.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, even if I did, you'll never find it.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_lifting his piece_] Oh, look at that... what's this? [_puts it down_] Could it be... checkmate? [_laughing_] I won, I won, I really won!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, I didn't gloat when I beat you all those times!

speaker: Frasier
text: No, but, I bet you wish you did now, huh?  Ha-ha, it feels great!

speaker: Martin
text: [_getting up_] All right, that's it.  I'm going to bed.  And I never want to hear the word "chess," or "board," or "chessboard" again!  That's it, got it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine.  Fine, Dad.  Goodnight.  Geez, lighten up!  It's only a game!  _Martin turns and stares at Frasier.  FADE TO:  Scene Seven -- Still Later that Night: Frasier pokes his head into Martin's room.  The sliver of light from the door shines in Martin's face, waking him up._

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad?  Dad?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, jeez...

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, please, just one question: did you let me win?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, for crying out loud, Frasier...

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, please, did you play your best?

speaker: Martin
text: For five thousand bucks?  What do you think?

speaker: Frasier
text: You wouldn't just be saying that?

speaker: Martin
text: [_sighs_] On your mother's grave, may lightning strike me down, I, Martin Crane, swear on the holiest of Bibles, you won, I lost, fair and square, cross my heart and hope to go to sleep.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: You're welcome.  _Frasier closes the door.  Martin starts to nod off again.  Frasier cracks the door again and sticks his head back in._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_guilty_] I'm sorry I beat you, Dad.
